author: PeeOnManning
body: Because MSM was conditioning people to take bear positions for September noise about how September is bad but September is going to be very bull and will happen when volume picks up. I highly recommend reading Betting Resource's quarterly outlook. They have been spot on. To summarize, do not short the market yet because the melt up phase is not complete and the big vertical melt up is yet to come. Multi year bear market will come but not yet.  Don't listen to any noise. I highly recommend following Aswath Damodaran, Mark Meldrum and Betting Resource to get the best market guidance. Don't be fooled by the sports content of BR, their quarterly outlook and ticker suggestion for stocks and option are priceless.  Tesla bullish, don' let any quick pull backs shake your hands. Tesla to test all time high and form double top by or just after next earning and if volume picks up we will see 1k easily. I highly doubt multi year bear market will start before tesla cracks $1000.

author: KenBalbari
body:
I posted this response in another forum, but should probably put it here:

The other index you are pointing to is based on new leases only. And most of the increase is just in the last few months. But it takes a year for most leases to actually expire. So it will take a year for that all to show in CPI data.

Consider where we were just in June, per:

https://www.apartmentguide.com/blog/apartment-guide-annual-rent-report/

Year over year:

    -3.1% 0-BR
    +5.2% 1-BR
    +4.8% 2-BR
    -1.4% 3-BR

That reflects data only through the end of May. But as of then, some apartments (both studio and larger apartments) were actually still down year over year.

So even if new leases increased 8% in the next two months, if that only impacts ~ 1/6 of apartments, that might only cause overall rents to increase by ~ 1.35%.

Eventually you will see higher increases in the CPI data though, there will just be a little more lag there. Recent increases haven't actually impacted most renters yet.

author: jnolsen94
body:
I was in the exact same position! I had one DIS share I got when I was 10. When the TA switched from Broadridge to Computershare and the price fell a bit, I decided to buy more. 

Unfortunately, a USD account of some kind is necessary, or at least it was when I last bought. I personally have a US account with RBC Bank (a wholly owned subsidiary of RBC, but based in the US). It's technically a different bank, but under the umbrella of the RBC family. I'm not sure whether CS would accept a USD account from a Canadian institution, although I assume they would, but it may be worth a phone call to their help line to get confirmation before looking to open a US account. I don't want to give any incorrect advice. 

There are a couple of forms that are worth filling out too. The W8-BEN form should reduce the foreign resident withholding tax from 30% to 15% (once DIS reinstates the dividend), and I would certainly consider the DRIP as well. At a 1-1.5% yield some people don't bother, but I do it because I'd rather have fractions of shares added to my account than a $10 deposit to my bank.

CS usually has good customer service, and DIS is a solid long-term hold. Hope this helps a little :)

author: redratus
body:
Dive in with the S&P500. The risks of this ETF are low and the upside is fairly steady. DCA in because you never know what will happen tomorrow. This should make up the bulk of your portfolio for now—and for most people, forever. You can also consider VTI (for mid and small cap exposure) and VT (for international exposure), and QQQ (a slightly more aggressive approach with just 100 top companies, but lately performing very well)

Then start to delve into stocks from companies that are established and whose charts have historically gone up over the years. I like to call these “steady gainers”, these are your FAAMGs, V, BX, etc. Consider cutting out the ones that have underperformed the S&P500 significantly for years unless you have good reason to believe there’s going to br a breakout. Buy the ones that consistently beat it. No stock only goes up, but some come surprisingly close. DCA into these as well.

After this you can think about more complicated plays (stocks that have been down for years but may reverse, newer/less established companies) but understand thats inherently more risky.

Good luck. If you diversify you will have some losers but hopefully, provided you hold your picks for years and dont panic sell, your gains will outweigh your losses.

author: jubothecat
body:
Intel said it was going to build the world's fastest super computer like 10 years ago. Now, they were supposed to deliver it years ago, and they still don't have the technology to make what they said they would. Even if released today it would now only be like the 3rd fastest because they waited too long.
Tldr: even if Intel has these new government contracts, they are so far behind that they have a lot longer of a journey to be the best chip maker than people think (most laymen don't even know AMD is better right now).

If there's limited enough suppliers (like the AMD/Intel/NVidia trio), they can keep prices up without crossing the line of overtly colluding. Creating and manufacturing a powerful CPU is very costly and the only edge players like Apple have no interest in driving prices down.

author: Jaypalm
body: ARM doesn’t make chips. Neither does AMD. ARM is an architecture, like x86. It’s an IP company. AMD designs and sells CPUs. As the underdog in the desktop CPU market they would be hurting themselves to collude with Intel when what they’re actually doing is making better products and undercutting Intel’s prices. I’m not saying there isn’t market collusion, but your arguments will have more merit if you actually know what you’re talking about.

author: Xx_Majesticface_xX
body: TSMC is a fairly well known stock, however, I’m placing my bets on Global Foundries. While there were talks a few months ago in regards to Intel acquiring them, a lot of electronics that don’t require high end semi conductors(7nm TSMC, 8nm Samsung, 10nm Intel) are made using cheap, larger nodes that are less efficient. Global foundries failed to develop high end chips after they abandoned their rnd, but they hold a 15% market share(at last check) in markets which use lower grade nodes. Best part is, that they are supposedly going public in 2022. I personally think that this is a wise investment, though a rather obvious one, as any company which is trusted by the US government and hold a market share in a sector worth billions is a simple stock to buy

author: daaammmN
body:
It all depends on if you overpaid or not.

Intel was almost at the 80$ mark in the 2000s.

Since then it has grown a lot, but still, 20 years later and it never reached its all time high.

This just proves that you can overpay for growth.
If you are overpaying, you might not see an increase for many years to come

I haven't dug into MasterCard, but I did for Visa.

IMO, Visa (and most of the market) is overpriced. The growth that Visa is projecting (mid teens) for the next 5 years is already priced in.

If the bull market continues, the stock price might increase, but it's just a matter of time before the correction arrives and reality kicks in.

I want to own Visa, I like it very much. They have been buying back shares like crazy, which is awesome. It's on my watchlist. But it still has to drop a lot for me to be a buyer. I have no doubt that it will be a buy at some point in the future though.

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.

author: MentalValueFund
body:
The fact you think the 7nm naming scheme from AMD is comparable to the naming scheme from Intel shows me you don’t know much about semiconductors.

I’m not stating Intel isn’t behind the ball on manufacturing at the moment relative to TSMC, but an AMD 7nm design is equivalent to an Intel 10nm design. The naming conventions are literally market bullshit that haven’t meant anything since we moved to FinFET.

author: donktastic
body:
That's not completely true and even if it was it doesn't matter. The proprietary tech steps are all done in secure locations like the US, Israel and Ireland with the US doing 100% of their R&D. The R&D sites are massive and also do manufacturing which handles the most top secret stuff, like US military stuff. Asia only gets the cost saving steps that are not sensitive, like packaging. 

If shit hit the fan and world war 3 broke out, Intel could easily do 100% of its process in the US or allied countries. The most important part being that Intel is a US company, is based in the USA and is invested in the success of the nation.

author: Overhaul2977
body:
AMD’s profit margin is pretty good, they are taking market share from intel and approaching Nvidia in performance for their GPUs, and they are innovating well under current management. The problem with your analysis is you’re looking at book value, you need to look at future growth and both companies they can take market share have a fair amount higher market cap, meaning it has plenty of space to grow if things keep going well for them. The stock market cares about future growth, not too much on past performance.

To give you a basic idea of investing, there are four types of companies - Dogs, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Stars. AMD is at the Question Mark phase that is almost to Star. They are taking market share in a fast growing area. The typical investor strategy in that situation is to “buy”.

author: merlinsbeers
body:
IBM made probably the biggest mistake in business history by giving Microsoft and Intel the ability to make computers on the PC architecture without IBM involvement.

They could have owned that whole ecosystem and leveraged their incredible brand recognition to attract the talent that made it happen.

But, if they had, IBM management would have overcontrolled it so we'd probably all be using Macs and talking about PC only in conversations with words like Amiga, Imsai, and Heathkit.

author: Summebride
body:
Stocks means stock market securities that you've surely heard of, Microsoft, Intel, JP Morgan, etc.

Bonds are a timed instrument where you lend your money to something and they pay it back later, with a slight amount extra.

Bonds have traditionally been for old people as they neither go up or down very much, and are predictable.  

Stocks can change in value radically and have traditionally been recommended for young  people so if you lose a lot of value, you have time to make it up.  

Blended fund just means a mix of those two kinds of things.  

At 23 there's no other choice than stock.  

AAR% likely means average annual return.  So if the AAR% was 4% and you have 1000 placed there, it would have gained about $40 during the year.  

Bunds are have recently been returning close to nothing.  Someday that might change but for now they're pretty much a worthless option for you.

author: LastTradeTonight
body:
I know YouTube is filled with peep calling the wheel “free” money. 

Long term you won’t get the same raw SPY return. 
It’s less volatile and more income driven. Also the capital lock-up is less per contract per 100 shares. 
Straight CC on SPY makes more sense than the put side bc it can get you a 70/30 risk profile with higher income. 


If you don’t care about income and are long-term investor than buy-hold is going to work better than the wheel. 

Personally, when I run the wheel it’s on a large cap with good options volume that has some vol but over all pretty stable. In the past companies like BAC, AAPL, INTC.  I haven’t run it since last year for obvious reasons.

body:
Yes and INTC is not a tech company.  I've been in the datacenter field for many years and I'm indifferent to brand, I'm mostly looking at energy efficiency, tech advancements.  Someone wanted to invest in Intel last week and I spelled out why not.  Originally my thesis was around 2016 when I bought AMD and Intel had Brian K was head of Intel.  This is no go and it may turn around a bit on buybacks, financial engineering they have a ton of money but it's not on the back of technology.  

Any non boomer working in cloud computing/semi field can tell you INTC is not where you want to put your money.  I believe Pat is more tech inclined but it's a long road and in the mean time you can invest in AMD, TSM, NVDA, AMZN, MSFT, APPL etc if you want exposure to semi or cloud computing.

Your comments seem like you are a 5 year old.

This is not the case for Apple, but it is not because of "super smart people", it is because they still seem to innovate and expand.

Also, do you even know what exactly Apple are planning on doing in the healthcare and EV? Who their competition is in each of these fields?

author: UncleFupa
body:
I work in the hardware security space... I've been to enough conferences to know for a fact the government is throwing a significant amount of money into this field.. billions...  At one point they were talking about standing up their own foundry...

The chip shortage combined with the need to have secure devices is forcing the government to be there funding into producing this stuff at home and not overseas.  

It seemed like it barely made the news, but a few weeks ago, it was announced Intel won the contract for government chips.  This was huge news to me. It's an undisclosed amount, but if I had to guess, it's not insignificant. And these are the type of contacts that once they get going, it's almost impossible to end.  Intel will be the government's arm for anything hardware related from here on out.  Sort of like Boeing or any defense company.

author: SnipahShot
body:
1. Pfizer.

The stock dropped after the FDA approval and by the end of the year they have the booster EUA request for the general public (already requested). They have their protease inhibitor that might completely obliterate the worst thing in Covid - The infection rate, which they will request EUA in the last quarter of the year.

2. Intel 

Intel has been beat for a while due to nothing of significance. Now they are coming with a new CPU Alder Lake which seems to surpass what AMD has to offer and also seems to be cheaper. Intel is also releasing a new gaming GPU, which is the first time for Intel to release a gaming one so it opens a brand new market for them. It also seems like this GPU will be able to compete against the top of Nvidia and AMD, while possibly being cheaper, if the CPU pricings are an indication.    
Also Intel is investing in their foundries with support from the US government, in order to manufacture chips outside of China.

author: Opeth4Lyfe
body: Because it’s trading rich right now. No matter how wonderful a company is it can still be over valued. Look at Intel, Cisco, GE, Amazon in the tech bubble. Tons of potential growth, lots of enthusiasm about their futures, no one thought they would go down. They corrected by as much as 90% in some cases…but on average lost 70% of their value. Amazon went from 113 to 6 but the company was in tremendous shape and growing incredibly fast. Would have taken over a decade to recover…and most of those companies are still not back at their previous ATH.

author: not_creative1
body:
As someone who works in this industry in silicon valley, main problem Intel has is talent. 

Intel has hemorrhaged talent to Apple, AMD, Nvidia over the last 5 years. Intel is no where near competitive in pay compared to those companies and are losing people left and right. I know several of my friends who left Intel for companies like Apple, qualcomm and so on.

Intel needs a revival from the ground up. Intel has a massive layer of middle managers who dont do much but have been around for 10+ years and do not plan on moving. But the young talented engineers, who are the actual foot soldiers who work on the products are leaving in droves.


Intel needs a complete overhaul of its culture, management and compensation structure. I dont know if they can do that in time.

author: vansterdam_city
body:
There are a lot of dividend related posts today but this might be the dumbest.

A good dividend stock is something that you see a basically infinite time horizon for (let’s say 30 years). Coca Cola 30 years ago is a classic example, its a product that doesn’t change much and was likely be enjoyed by people for decades to come. 

Technology is by nature prone to innovative disruption. This is horrible for the prospects of a dividend paying company. I couldn’t think of a worse two words to pair together on an investment choice. 

Technology is for GROWTH as you disrupt the market. Buying into the mature end of the cycle is right when you are prone to being disrupted yourself by a new player. 

Some of your picks like Intel and Cisco could easily be disrupted and become dinosaurs. For a measly 2%-ish dividend? You have to be kidding me to think this is a sane investment thesis.

author: hondajacka
body:
Valuation is a function of growth. In the long term, if your company is not showing growth in revenue and earning, your valuation/stock price is not going to increase.

I do think Intel’s current products are better for enterprise, but going forward, it is much more likely AMD will catch up to those features and will keep putting pressure on Intel’s margins. And the reason I said AMD would have even more market share cause of supply constraints is because at least in the consumer segment and earlier this year, their CPUs have been difficult to find and overpriced when available. I wanted to buy an AMD PC but couldn’t and had to go with Intel.

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

author: hondajacka
body:
As an investor, what matters is growth, which translates to increase in stock price. High revenue but no growth still means stagnant stock price. I don’t think Intel would go out of business but they are slowly loosing market share.

And one of the reason why their revenue is so high is because they do design and fab, whereas AMD is fabless. Market share is a better comparison. AMD has 22.5% of the x86 market Q2 2021 vs 18.3% Q2 2020. And the main reason why AMD didn’t gain even more is because of supply constraints, which should normalize in 1-2 more years.

I do agree Pat Gelsinger is trying his best to turn the company around, but changes in this industry take many years to materialize so in the meantime, you just have to take his word for it. IMO, the culture at Intel has become that like of a slow behemoth with fiefdoms where people are resistant to change. And compared to competitors, their employees are underpaid, not helped by their stagnant stock prices. So they are not attracting anywhere close to the best people.

author: MentalValueFund
body:
Jesus Christ this is one of the dumbest responses ive ever read. As an investor, what matters is valuation, regardless of whether you’re a growth investor or a value investor. You buy and sell equities at a current valuation based on what the future will bring. If there’s a growth rate you expect, then you find the fair valuation according to your macro assumptions and bring it back to the present. 

Lol, Intel’s revenues are not high because they run foundries. It’s their margins that are wider because of that. 

The main reason why AMD didn’t gain more is because the commercial data center market doesn’t up and change chips every release. They run on 4-6 year cycles and trickle into new chip generations. This buys even more time for Intel to steady the bleeding and bring out adequate competitor to stabilize their market share. Despite your argument below with links about data center deals, Intel is still pumping out $7bn in pure data center products (up 16% yoy) while AMD only managed $1.6bn in “Enterprise, Embedded, and Semi-Custom” products (the specifically don’t split out data center because they don’t want everyone to see how uncompetitive they are with Intel financially). Finally there’s the fact that AMD’s data center product is just flat out immature. Cores aren’t everything and data centers stick with Intel because of the full suite of features and functionality at the enterprise level that AMD simply hasn’t caught up with.
